vocabulary.definition: person who studies or grows plants like flowers, fruit and vegetables
thorough understanding of a subject, gained from experience and study, that goes beyond the basic facts
searching a wide area with your eyes to find some particular thing
above and beyond what is expected; when referring to certainty, it means without any doubt
negative belief about something which is unfair or untrue
act with care and attention to avoid possible risks or dangers; be careful

script.speaker: Pippa
script.text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Pippa.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: And I'm Beth. Foraging is the activity of walking in the countryside, looking for plants you can eat that grow in the wild. That's anything from blackberries and chestnuts to mushrooms and wild garlic. It's something humans have always done and recently it's become fashionable among groups of young people. Pippa, have you ever been foraging?

script.speaker: Pippa
script.text: Yes, we used to go and pick blackberries when I was younger, but I haven't really done it as an adult, and I would be a bit nervous to look for mushrooms or things like that. What about you?

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: I'm exactly the same. If I see a blackberry on a bush, I will eat it! But mushrooms? No. Too scary.

script.speaker: Pippa
script.text: So, in this episode, we'll meet two young women from different countries who are passionate about foraging wild food. They're both self-taught, having learned to forage by studying the natural world around them, and it's important to say that they only eat what they can identify with one hundred percent certainty, sticking to the rule, "If in doubt leave it out!"

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: We'll also be learning some useful new words and phrases, all of which you'll find on our website, bbclearningenglish.com. But before that, I have a question for you, Pippa. As mentioned, when foraging you must know for certain what is safe to eat. Something definitely not safe to eat is the mushroom Death Cap. As the name suggests, it's one of the world's deadliest mushrooms, and it's common across the British Isles, but what colour is it? Are Death Cap mushrooms: a) brown, b) white, or c) red?

script.speaker: Pippa
script.text: I'm going to say, if it's dangerous maybe it's red.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: OK. Well, we'll find out later in the programme. First, let's meet Roushanna Gray, a wild-food forager living in Cape Point, South Africa. Roushanna learned how to forage from her mother-in-law, as she explains here to BBC World Service programme The Conversation:

script.speaker: Roushanna Gray
script.text: So, she is a

script.speaker: horticulturalist
script.text: . She has a

script.speaker: deep knowledge
script.text: of plants. And so, I would be, kind of,

script.speaker: scanning
script.text: the landscape and learning about these new plants – or new to me – and wondering if you could eat them. Something that's incredibly important in foraging is to know

script.speaker: a hundred and ten percent
script.text: if you can eat it – positive identification of the plant. And so, she was my plant person.

script.speaker: Pippa
script.text: Roushanna's mother-in-law is a

script.speaker: horticulturalist
script.text: – a person who studies or grows plants such as flowers, fruits and vegetables. She has a

script.speaker: deep knowledge
script.text: of the wild plants growing in nature. A

script.speaker: deep knowledge
script.text: means a thorough understanding of a subject gained from experience and study, not just knowing the basic facts.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: One skill foragers need is

script.speaker: scanning
script.text: the landscape.

script.speaker: Scanning
script.text: means searching a wide area with your eyes to find some particular thing – in this case, edible plants and herbs.

script.speaker: Pippa
script.text: And of course, Roushanna only eats plants that she can positively identify – plants that she knows

script.speaker: a hundred and ten percent
script.text: are safe to eat. Here, the idiom

script.speaker: a hundred and ten percent
script.text: means Roushanna is completely sure. She has no doubt. And that's important, as the consequences of eating poisonous plants are serious – sickness or even death.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: Our second female forager, Emily Smith, moved to rural Japan to work on a project cataloguing and collecting wild mushrooms. With around 5,000 varieties, 300 of which are edible, mushrooms are an important part of traditional Japanese cooking. But with names like Death Cap and a reputation for being poisonous, mushrooms are what many wild foragers worry about the most. Emily discussed these worries with BBC World Service programme The Conversation.

script.speaker: Emily Smith
script.text: That

script.speaker: stigma
script.text: is a bit misplaced, I think, because plants can be just as dangerous, if not more dangerous than mushrooms, and I think that mushrooms have been much maligned. I mean, you've got to

script.speaker: exercise caution
script.text: , as Roushanna said, in anything that you pick. You need to know what it is before you consume it. "If in doubt, throw it out!" is a very good phrase to say.

script.speaker: Pippa
script.text: Emily thinks there's a

script.speaker: stigma
script.text: around mushrooms. A

script.speaker: stigma
script.text: is a negative belief about something which is not necessarily true or fair. In fact, many plants are just as poisonous as mushrooms.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: The main thing is to

script.speaker: exercise caution
script.text: – to act with care and attention so as to avoid possible dangers. In other words, to be careful.

script.speaker: Pippa
script.text: And the best way of doing that is learning the difference between what's safe to eat and what's not. Speaking of which, what was the answer to your question, Beth?

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: Ah! I asked you, "What colour are Death Cap mushrooms?" You said red, which I also thought was the answer, but actually they are white. Right, it's time to recap the vocabulary we've learnt about foraging, starting with

script.speaker: horticulturalist
script.text: – a person who studies or grows plants.

script.speaker: Pippa
script.text: If you have a

script.speaker: deep knowledge
script.text: of a subject, you have a thorough understanding of it, gained from experience and study.

script.speaker: Scanning
script.text: involves searching a wide area with your eyes to find some particular thing.

script.speaker: Pippa
script.text: If you're

script.speaker: a hundred and ten percent
script.text: sure about something, you're absolutely certain. You have no doubt.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: A

script.speaker: stigma
script.text: is an unfair, negative belief about something.

script.speaker: Pippa
script.text: And finally, to

script.speaker: exercise caution
script.text: is a more formal way of saying to be careful – something you should definitely remember if you go wild foraging yourself! Once again, our six minutes are up. If you enjoyed this episode, you'll find a quiz and worksheet to practise the vocabulary on our website, bbclearningenglish.com. See you again soon. Bye for now!

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: Goodbye!

vocabulary.definition: term used to describe a large number of different things which all belong to a single common category
brushing and cleaning the coat of hair of a horse, dog or other animal
stage of life when a child grows into an adult because of changes in their body which allow them to have children
(child) who is looked after by the local authorities because they cannot be cared for by their parents or family; also known as a 'looked after child'
strong feeling of reliance and confidence between two people

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Neil.

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: And I'm Georgie. Neil, have you ever ridden a horse?

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Yes, I have. I can't say that I enjoyed it much. I was a bit scared to be honest. How about you?

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: I used to ride horses a lot actually. My favourite thing was to ride a horse through the countryside. I love horses. They're so majestic and lovely. The relationship between humans and horses has been close throughout history, but recently this has gone beyond riding horses for fun or using them for work. Equine Assisted Services, sometimes called horse therapy, is a health trend where caring and interacting with horses is used to heal physical and mental illness. Here's Datshiane Navanayaga, presenter of BBC World Service programme The Conversation, to explain:

script.speaker: Datshiane Navanayaga
script.text: Equine Assisted Services is now an

script.speaker: umbrella term
script.text: which encompasses a whole range of treatments, involving activities and interactions with horses to promote better human wellbeing.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Equine Assisted Services is an

script.speaker: umbrella term
script.text: – a term for a large number of different things which all belong to a single common category. So, horse therapy includes many activities, from feeling the horse's movement, which can help children with muscle disorders like cerebral palsy, to simply

script.speaker: grooming
script.text: the horse, which can help calm anxiety.

script.speaker: Grooming
script.text: a horse means cleaning and brushing the horse's coat of hair.

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: Various animals can be used in therapy, but horses are particularly suitable as they're very sensitive to human emotions. Being in contact with them affects the limbic area of the brain, dealing with stress. In this episode, we'll hear more about the horses helping people work through mental, emotional and physical challenges. And, as usual, we'll learn some useful new vocabulary.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: And remember, you'll find all the words and phrases from this episode on our website, bbclearningenglish.com

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: But now I have a question for you, Neil. We've heard some of the special qualities horses possess, but which of the following about horses is also true? Is it: a) horses always sleep standing up, b) horses can make over 100 sounds, or c) horses have almost 360-degree vision?

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Well, I'm sure I've seen a horse lying down so... I don't know about its vision though, so I'm going to say b) a horse can make over 100 sounds.

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: OK. Well, we'll find out the answer later in the programme. Horse therapist Claudia Nicholson first felt the healing power of horses as a child. She now runs her own centre for Equine Assisted Learning in the south of England, where she spoke with BBC World Service programme The Conversation.

script.speaker: Claudia Nicholson
script.text: I would spend

script.speaker: hours on end
script.text: sitting in a stable with my pony. I was going through

script.speaker: puberty
script.text: , my parents had separated, I had a lot of unanswered questions, and I would feel met and safe and held with the connection of the pony.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: As a child, Claudia spent

script.speaker: hours on end
script.text: with her pony. Phrases like

script.speaker: days
script.text: or

script.speaker: on end
script.text: mean days or hours doing something continuously, without stopping.

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: Spending time with her pony helped Claudia through

script.speaker: puberty
script.text: – the stage of life when a child grows into an adult because of changes in their body which allow them to have children.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: It was her teenage experiences that led Claudia to start her own horse therapy centre. She works a lot with teenage girls and children

script.speaker: in care
script.text: . A child

script.speaker: in care
script.text: is a child who's being looked after by the local authorities because they cannot be cared for by their parents or family. Here, Claudia talks more about her work with children and horses to BBC World Service's The Conversation:

script.speaker: Claudia Nicholson
script.text: It will take maybe a few sessions for a

script.speaker: relationship of trust
script.text: to be formed, and it's quite extraordinary to see a child that's experienced a lot of trauma, especially in these children

script.speaker: in care
script.text: .They can be brushing the pony's body. They might want to have a cry which they've been holding on to. The horse regulates them.

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: Many of the children Claudia works with suffer trauma. It takes time for them to build a

script.speaker: bond of trust
script.text: with their horse. The phrase

script.speaker: bond of trust
script.text: is a strong feeling of reliance and confidence between two people.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Horses really are special animals. They sense human feelings like fear or sadness through breath, heart rate and movement, and respond with gentleness and calm. This makes them perfect animal therapists. And that's not all! Right, Georgie? Let's find out the answer to your question.

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: Yes, Neil. Well, I asked you which sentence about horses was true, and you said that horses can make over 100 sounds... Sadly, that was the wrong answer. The correct answer was c) horses have near 360-degree vision, which is surprising.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Wow. That's amazing!

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: OK. Let's recap the vocabulary we've learned, starting with

script.speaker: umbrella term
script.text: – a term used to describe many different things which all belong to a single common category.

script.speaker: Grooming
script.text: an animal, like a horse or a dog, means brushing and cleaning its coat of hair.

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: If you do something for

script.speaker: hours on end
script.text: , you do it continuously, without stopping.

script.speaker: Puberty
script.text: is the stage of life when a child grows into an adult because of changes in their body which allow them to have children.

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: A child who is

script.speaker: in care
script.text: is being looked after by the local authorities because they cannot be cared for by their parents.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: And finally, a

script.speaker: bond of trust
script.text: is a strong feeling of reliance and confidence between two people. Once again, our six minutes are up, but remember you'll find a quiz and worksheet for this episode over on our website, bbclearningenglish.com. See you there soon, but for now it's goodbye!

script.speaker: Georgie
script.text: Goodbye!

vocabulary.definition: (idiom) something is the best and you won't find anything better
situation where one action causes many other similar actions to happen
an individual's subjective liking or disliking for something, based on their personal taste and opinion
(idiom) essential feature or element of something
relied upon to be the best thing for a particular purpose or situation
paste made of mashed avocado, lime juice and salt

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Neil.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: And I'm Beth. In Britain we call them crisps and you might know them as potato chips, but whatever you call them, these fried potato slices are probably the world's favourite snack. Neil, are you a big crisp eater and what's your favourite flavour?

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: I love crisps, Beth. They are my favourite snack.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: My favourite flavour is prawn cocktail, which is controversial because a lot of people don't like that flavour.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: I think my favourite is salt and vinegar.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: Yummy! You're making me hungry.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Well, crisps might be popular but with lots of oil and salt they're not the healthiest food. So, why do we love them so much? That's what BBC World Service programme The Food Chain wanted to find out. Here, presenter Ruth Alexander talks to Mitchell Dingwall, a food executive responsible for developing new crisp flavours:

script.speaker: Ruth Alexander
script.text: Why do we love crisps so much?

script.speaker: Mitchell Dingwall
script.text: Hmm. I think it's just that crunch, right?

script.speaker: can't beat
script.text: the crunch. And then that delicious, salty feeling in your mouth and it just becomes a

script.speaker: snowball effect
script.text: . You just want more of it!

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: For Mitchell, the best thing about crisps is the loud crunch. He says, "

script.speaker: You can't beat it
script.text: !" An idiom meaning something like: "That's the best thing and you won't find anything better!"

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Mitchell says once you've started eating crisps, it's hard to stop and you just want to eat more and more. He calls this a

script.speaker: snowball effect
script.text: – a situation where doing something causes other similar things to happen. You eat one crisp and before you know it, the whole packet's gone!

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: In this episode, we'll be visiting two countries in love with crisps and, as usual, we'll be learning some useful new words and phrases, all of which you can find on our website, bbclearningenglish.com.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: But first, I have a question for you, Beth. The record for the world's largest packet of crisps was recently broken in Saudi Arabia, but how much did the packet weigh? Was it: a) about 1.5 tonnes, b) about 2.5 tonnes, or c) about 3.5 tonnes?

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: OK. Wow! They are all huge! I'm going to guess about 3.5 tonnes.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: OK. We'll find out the answer later. Let's travel first to Singapore, home of Jolene Ng, a market research analyst who specialises in salty snacks. Here's Jolene talking with Ruth Alexander for BBC programme The Food Chain:

script.speaker: Ruth Alexander
script.text: Is the potato chip the most popular of all salty snacks?

script.speaker: Jolene Ng
script.text: It's very, very much dependent on

script.speaker: personal preference
script.text: but if I were to look at certain countries, you could see, like in the UK, it's very much

script.speaker: part and parcel
script.text: of life. You don't have it only during snack times. You have it with lunch as well. You put it… My husband's from the UK and he, kind of, puts it in his sandwich as well.

script.speaker: Ruth Alexander
script.text: Oh yeah, a cheese sandwich with a crisp inside. Oh yeah, that's great!

script.speaker: Jolene Ng
script.text: Exactly!

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: Jolene says the popularity of different snacks depends on

script.speaker: personal preference
script.text: – someone's subjective liking or disliking for something, based on their personal opinion.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: In some places, crisps are

script.speaker: part and parcel
script.text: of everyday life.

script.speaker: Part and parcel
script.text: means to be an essential element or feature of something. In Britain, crisps are so essential that people even eat crisp sandwiches!

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: But not everywhere is so in love with potato chips. Let's meet Jenny Martinez, a food vlogger from Mexico. In Mexico, tortilla corn chips are eaten instead of potato chips, and it's common to see street vendors selling bags of corn tortillas filled with different sauces. Here, Jenny tells Ruth Alexander more for BBC World Service programme The Food Chain:

script.speaker: Ruth Alexander
script.text: For you, which is your

script.speaker: go-to
script.text: snack – the tortilla chip or the potato chip?

script.speaker: Jenny Martinez
script.text: Definitely the tortilla chip.

script.speaker: Ruth Alexander
script.text: Why?

script.speaker: Jenny Martinez
script.text: Because you could do so many things – dip it in almost everything, adding some

script.speaker: guacamole
script.text: ,spicy salsa or just sour cream with a mixture of chipotle sauce.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Ruth asks if tortillas are Jenny's

script.speaker: go-to
script.text: snack. You can use the phrase

script.speaker: go-to
script.text: to describe something which is relied upon to be the best thing for a particular purpose. For example, for a lot of people, Wikipedia is the

script.speaker: go-to
script.text: website for online information.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: And Jenny thinks corn tortillas are especially good with

script.speaker: guacamole
script.text: , a paste made of mashed avocado… which sounds delicious and maybe a little healthier than a British crisp sandwich! Speaking of which, what was the answer to your question, Neil?

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: I asked you how heavy the world's largest bag of crisps was.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: And I said very heavy – over three and a half tonnes.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Well, it's not that big but the real answer is still enormous – about 1.5 tonnes. The bag, made in Riyadh, was nine metres tall.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: Yeah.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: OK. Let's recap the vocabulary we've learned, starting with the phrase

script.speaker: can't beat that
script.text: , meaning that something is the best and you won't find anything better.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: A

script.speaker: snowball effect
script.text: is a situation where one action causes other similar actions to happen.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Someone's

script.speaker: personal preference
script.text: is their subjective liking or disliking for something, based on their own opinion.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: To be

script.speaker: part and parcel
script.text: of something means to be an essential or integral feature of it.

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: And something which is described as the

script.speaker: go-to
script.text: can be relied upon as the best thing for a particular situation.

script.speaker: Beth
script.text: And finally,

script.speaker: guacamole
script.text: is a paste made of mashed avocado, lime juice and salt – delicious! Once again, our six minutes are up but if you're hungry for more, then head over to our website, bbclearningenglish.com, where you'll find a worksheet and quiz for this episode. See you again soon, but for now, goodbye!

script.speaker: Neil
script.text: Goodbye!
